title: Budweiser Brewer Anheuser-Busch Rises as Investors Toast Revived Hong Kong IPO
text:
Text size

Anheuser-Busch will list its Asian business in Hong Kong later this month

Budweiser brewer Anheuser-Busch InBev has revived plans to list its Asian business in Hong Kong with a slimmed down $4.84 billion IPO, sending shares higher.

The back story.

Anheuser-Busch’s management has pledged to reduce its debt, which remains high at $104 billion following its acquisition of rival SABMiller in 2016.

In July the company canceled plans for what would have been the largest IPO of the year, opting against the $9.8 billion listing of its Asian business in Hong Kong, citing “prevailing market conditions.”

Trade tensions between the U.S. and China had hit markets and Hong Kong itself has been plagued with protests.

Less than a week later, it agreed to sell its Australian assets to Japanese brewer Asahi Group Holdings for $11.3 billion, putting a dent in its debt pile.

Earlier this month shares, which have risen 53% this year, climbed on reports it could resurrect its Hong Kong IPO.

What’s new.

Anheuser-Busch has revived plans to list its Asian business with a slimmed down $4.84 billion IPO in Hong Kong.

The company’s Asia Pacific arm will begin taking orders on Wednesday with a planned listing on Sept. 30, according to the Wall Street Journal, citing people familiar with the matter.

The Budweiser brewer’s Australian unit had been part of the initial IPO plan before being sold to Asahi.

The revised listing would be the year’s second largest IPO behind Uber’s $8.1 billion debut in May.

Anheuser-Busch shares climbed 1.7% on Tuesday, just weeks after Barron’s predicted a relaunched IPO would send the stock higher.

Moving forward.

Rising beer sales - the fastest growth in five years - and the prospect of a blockbuster Asian IPO lifted the Belgian brewer’s share price earlier this year until the cancellation of the latter held it back.

With the IPO back in the mix, and the brewer’s shift towards more expensive premium products, investors could well be toasting further gains soon.
